description: Teacher receives a data‑driven visual‑aid recommendation after the assistant analyzes exit‑ticket confusion, curriculum standards, and classroom performance metrics.

messages.content: You are ClassPulse Assistant, an AI that continuously monitors student participation, grades, and curriculum standards, then suggests real‑time lesson adjustments, targeted interventions, and keeps teachers informed with actionable insights.

I just collected the exit tickets from today's Algebra lesson (lesson_id: L12). Many students wrote things like:

- "I'm not sure how to factor the quadratic.
- "The formula part confused me.
- "I don't get why we set the equation to zero.

Can you suggest a visual aid that would help clarify solving quadratic equations?
Got it. I’ll first analyze the sentiment of the exit‑ticket responses to confirm the level of confusion.

messages.content: The analysis confirms strong confusion (sentiment score 32) and frustration among the students. Let me pull the relevant curriculum standards for this lesson so we can align any visual aid with the required outcomes.

{"standards": [{"code": "CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.7.EE.B.4", "description": "Solve quadratic equations in one variable by factoring, completing the square, the quadratic formula, and by graphing."}], "objectives": ["Students will understand the structure of a quadratic equation", "Students will apply the quadratic formula correctly"]}
Great. Next I’ll retrieve the most recent formative assessment scores for this lesson so we can gauge how well the class is mastering the objectives.
Attendance today was 96 % and a quick poll showed an engagement score of 58 / 100. Using these metrics, I’ll generate a lesson‑adjustment recommendation that includes a suitable visual aid.

{"recommendation": "Add a dynamic, interactive graphing simulation that visualizes the parabola as coefficients change. Allocate 10 minutes for a step‑by‑step walkthrough of the quadratic formula using the simulation, followed by a guided practice activity. This addresses CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.7.EE.B.4 and targets the observed confusion. Provide a printable one‑page visual aid summarizing the formula steps with annotated graph snapshots.", "visual_aid": "https://example.com/resources/quadratic‑simulation"}

Based on the data, I recommend using an interactive graphing simulation that lets students see how the parabola shifts as the a, b, c coefficients change. You can run a 10‑minute walkthrough of the quadratic formula with the simulation, then let students explore on their own. I’ve prepared a one‑page printable visual aid that summarizes each step and includes annotated screenshots.

I’ll send the link and the printable aid to you now.

arguments.message: Recommendation for lesson L12: Use the interactive quadratic simulation (https://example.com/resources/quadratic‑simulation) and the attached one‑page visual aid to address student confusion. See attached PDF.

messages.content: The recommendation has been sent to your device. Let me know if you’d like me to schedule the simulation for tomorrow’s class or if you need any additional resources.
